name: Event Type Classification
description: Classifies a platform event into one of six communication types based on observable event characteristics. Each question asks about something the product team concretely knows about their event — no circular reasoning or presupposed knowledge of the outcome.

start.text: Is the end user actively doing something when this event occurs?
start.description: The event is a direct result of the user's current action: clicking a button, submitting a form, making an API call, uploading a file, configuring settings.

options.label: Yes, the user is performing an action
options.description: The user triggered this directly — they clicked, submitted, requested, typed, or configured something

options.label: No, this happens independently
options.description: A system process, admin change, scheduled event, or background operation — not triggered by the current user's action

user_problem_check.text: Is there a problem, error, or warning?
user_problem_check.description: Something went wrong, failed, or needs the user's attention to fix: errors, failed requests, permission issues, exceeded limits, or warnings about potential problems.

options.label: Yes, something is wrong
options.description: An error occurred, a request failed, a limit was exceeded, or there is a warning about a potential issue

options.label: No, everything is fine
options.description: The action succeeded or the user is in the middle of a normal workflow

user_form_check.text: Is this about guiding the user's input in a form field?
user_form_check.description: The user is actively filling in a form and needs guidance: required-field indicators, format rules (e.g. email format), character limits, password requirements, uniqueness checks.

options.label: Yes, it's form input guidance
options.description: Helping the user enter valid data: required fields, format hints, constraints, live validation feedback

options.label: No, this isn't about form input
options.description: The user completed an action or started a process — not actively typing into a field

user_outcome.text: What best describes the outcome of the user's action?
user_outcome.description: The user's action succeeded. How should the system respond?

options.label: A record or receipt the user needs to keep
options.description: The user will need to reference this later: generated API key, confirmation number, transaction ID, created resource with details

options.label: An ongoing process begins that shows progress
options.description: Something is now running: file upload, model training, deployment pipeline, data export, batch processing

options.label: The action is acknowledged
options.description: A quick 'it worked' confirmation: 'Saved', 'Copied', 'Deleted', 'Updated' — appears briefly, then disappears

system_temporality.text: Does this represent an ongoing condition or a specific event?
system_temporality.description: Ongoing conditions are current states that persist and may change at any moment (like a health dashboard). Specific events are discrete things that happened or will happen at a particular time (like a maintenance window).

options.label: An ongoing condition that may change at any time
options.description: Current state that persists: service health, API availability, quota usage, connection status, model availability

options.label: A specific event, change, or announcement
options.description: Something discrete: scheduled maintenance, model deprecation, pricing change, outage, security advisory, feature release

result_error_warning.purpose: Communicate problems that need the user's attention. Shown inline where the problem occurred.
examples: API rate limit exceeded — wait 60 seconds or upgrade your plan
Invalid model parameter: temperature must be between 0 and 2
Permission denied: you don't have access to this model
Connection lost — check your network and try again

result_validation.purpose: Guide users toward valid input before submission. Shown inline next to the field.
examples: API key name must be 3–50 characters
Required: select at least one model
This name is already taken — choose a different one
Password must contain at least one number and one special character

result_transactional_confirmation.purpose: Confirm completed transactions. Serves as a receipt the user can reference later.
examples: API key created — copy it now, it won't be shown again
Subscription activated — Invoice #12345 sent to your email
Model deployment complete — Endpoint: https://api.example.com/v1/gpt4

result_status_display_process.purpose: Show progress of a user-initiated process. Persists until it completes or fails.
examples: Upload progress: 67%
Model training: Step 3 of 5
Deployment in progress...
channels: Persistent UI element (progress bar, spinner, status badge)

result_feedback.purpose: Acknowledge the user's action and maintain interaction flow. Brief, transient, and auto-dismissing — no record needed.
examples: Settings saved
API key copied to clipboard
Configuration updated
Model removed from favorites

result_status_display_system.purpose: Show current system state and health. Always visible on the relevant screen, updates automatically.
examples: API Status: Operational
Model availability: 3 of 5 active
Quota usage: 85% (8,500 / 10,000 requests)
Connection: Online
channels: Persistent UI element (badge, indicator, dashboard widget)

result_notification.purpose: Inform users about important events, changes, or announcements. Reaches users through multiple channels.
examples: Scheduled maintenance on March 5, 2–4 AM CET
Model gpt-3.5-turbo will be deprecated on April 15
Platform outage: Image generation service unavailable
New feature: Custom fine-tuning now available

continueWith.reason: Notifications require a severity classification to determine urgency, channel behavior, and escalation timeline.
